cards.text: Offer to help someone clean up after playtime.
I make the world better when I’m kind.
Say something nice to the person sitting next to you.
Hold the door or make space for someone today.
Kind words can change someone’s day, and I have them.
Draw a picture or write a note to make someone smile.
Share your toys, crayons, or snacks with a friend.
I’m proud to be someone who cares about others.
Ask someone, 'How are you feeling?' and really listen.
Give a compliment about effort, like 'You worked hard!.'
Every kind act I do makes my heart stronger.
Let someone go first in line or during a game.
Say 'thank you' to someone who helps you today.
Do something helpful without being asked.
I like being a helper and spreading kindness.
Smile at three people today.
Pick up something that isn’t yours and put it away.
Kindness always starts with me.
Invite someone new to play with you.
Say, 'You’re awesome,' and tell them why.
Listen when someone else is talking.
I show respect by treating others the way I want to be treated.
Ask before using something that isn’t yours.
Say 'please' and 'thank you' today.
I can disagree kindly and still be respectful.
Keep your space clean and tidy for everyone.
Let someone go ahead of you in line.
Respect means I care about others’ feelings and things.
Use a calm voice, even when you feel upset.
Say something nice about someone’s effort or creativity.
I am proud to show good manners.
Take turns and wait patiently for yours.
Be gentle with things that belong to others.
My words and actions show I care about others.
Thank someone who helps you today.
Include someone who’s being left out.
Respect helps everyone feel safe and happy.
Keep your hands and feet to yourself.
Speak kindly to adults, teachers, and friends.
I respect myself by making good choices.
Try something new, even if it feels scary.
I can do brave things, even when I’m nervous.
Stand up for someone who needs help.
Raise your hand to share an idea in class.
Being brave means I try, even if I might make a mistake.
Tell the truth, even when it’s hard.
Ask a question when you don’t understand something.
I can be scared and brave at the same time.
Try again after something didn’t work out.
Invite someone new to play or talk with you.
Courage grows when I practice being brave.
Do something kind without being asked.
Apologize if you hurt someone’s feelings.
I am strong, smart, and brave.
Try a food, game, or activity you haven’t tried before.
Speak up for what’s right, even if no one else does.
I’m proud of myself when I try my best.
Ask someone if they’d like to be friends.
Finish something you started, even if it’s hard.
I am brave enough to be myself.
Try again when something doesn’t work the first time.
I can do hard things, even when they take time.
Finish a task before starting a new one today.
Take a deep breath and keep going when it gets tricky.
Every time I try again, I get stronger.
Work on something a little longer than you did yesterday.
Break a big job into smaller steps and do one right now.
Mistakes help me learn and grow.
Ask for help and then try one more time on your own.
Keep working until you feel proud of your effort.
I don’t give up when things are hard.
Try something new that used to feel too hard.
Tell someone about something you worked hard to finish.
I am proud of my effort, not just my results.
Take one more try before asking for help.
Encourage someone else to keep going too.
Even small progress counts — I’m doing great.
Look back at something you’ve improved at since you started.
Remind yourself, 'I can figure this out.'
I am strong, patient, and brave enough to keep trying.
Say one thing you like about yourself today.
I believe in myself and what I can do.
Try something new, even if you feel unsure.
Stand tall, smile, and walk like you mean it.
I am brave enough to try new things.
Tell someone about something you’re proud of.
Ask a question when you’re curious.
I’m good at learning, growing, and figuring things out.
Practice saying something kind to yourself in the mirror.
Take your time and do your best — that’s enough.
I can do things that used to feel hard.
Try helping someone else — confidence grows when we share it.
Speak clearly and look at people when you talk.
I’m proud of who I am becoming.
Try again after a mistake — that’s real confidence.
Do one small thing today all by yourself.
I don’t have to be perfect to be proud of myself.
Say 'I can do this' before starting something new.
Share something you made or built with someone else.
I am confident, capable, and full of great ideas.
Say thank you to someone who helped you today.
I’m thankful for the people who care about me.
Write or draw three things that make you happy.
Tell a friend or teacher you appreciate them.
Good things happen around me every day.
Notice something beautiful outside and say, 'I’m glad I saw that.'
Thank someone who usually doesn’t get thanked — like the janitor or lunch helper.
I’m grateful for today and the little things in it.
Share something you’re thankful for during dinner or class.
Make a card or note to show appreciation to someone special.
I can always find something to be thankful for.
Say thank you and look the person in the eyes.
Think of one person who makes you feel happy and say why.
I feel good when I notice what’s good.
Pick three things in your room that make you thankful.
Write a thank-you note or draw a picture for someone.
Gratitude helps me see how lucky I am.
Take a minute to think of one great thing that happened today.
Say something nice to a person who made your day easier.
I’m thankful for today, tomorrow, and all I have.
Tell the truth, even if it feels hard.
I am brave enough to tell the truth.
Admit when you made a mistake and try to fix it.
Be honest about how you feel with someone you trust.
Being honest makes me trustworthy.
Tell the truth, even when no one is watching.
Keep your promises today.
I feel proud when I tell the truth.
If you forget something, tell the truth instead of making up a story.
Tell someone one thing you’re thankful for about them.
Honesty helps others trust me.
Say what you mean in a kind way.
Own up to something small today and fix it right away.
I can be kind and honest at the same time.
If you see something wrong, tell an adult you trust.
Practice saying 'That was my fault' and how to make it better.
I tell the truth because it feels good inside.
Think before you speak to make sure your words are true and kind.
Return something that doesn’t belong to you.
Being honest shows my heart is strong and good.
Clean up your space without being asked.
I can be trusted to take care of my things.
Finish your homework or task before playing.
Feed a pet, water a plant, or care for something small.
I feel proud when I do what I say I’ll do.
Put your backpack, shoes, or toys where they belong.
Remind yourself of one thing you’re responsible for today.
I take care of myself and the things I use.
Help someone finish a job or clean-up task.
Be on time for something today.
Responsibility means doing my best, even when no one’s watching.
Ask, 'What can I do to help?' before being told.
Do something helpful around the house all by yourself.
I am someone others can count on.
Take care of your body — brush teeth, wash hands, get ready on time.
Do your best work, even when no one is checking.
I’m proud of myself when I follow through.
Make your bed or tidy your room before starting your day.
Keep track of your things and return them where they go.
I can be responsible, dependable, and kind.
Ask someone, 'How are you feeling?' and really listen.
I care about how others feel.
Notice when someone looks sad and see if you can help.
Share your toys, space, or time with someone who needs it.
I can put myself in someone else’s shoes.
Say kind words when someone makes a mistake.
Ask someone new to join your game or group.
I’m a good friend because I listen and care.
Give a hug, high-five, or smile to someone who needs it.
If someone is upset, ask what might make them feel better.
I show empathy when I listen with my heart.
Compliment someone who looks nervous or shy.
Say 'I understand' when someone tells you how they feel.
I try to see things from others’ points of view.
Offer to help a classmate who’s struggling.
Think about how your actions affect others.
I can make people feel seen and understood.
Say something kind to someone who seems left out.
Listen to someone’s story without interrupting.
Empathy helps me connect and care for others.
